predictions: The Prime Ministers of India and Japan met in Tokyo.

India's new Prime Minister Narendra Modi meets his Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe in Tokyo during his first major foreign visit since his election victory in May to discuss economic and security policy relations.
Mr. Modi is on a five-day trip to Japan to strengthen economic ties with the world's third-largest economy.
Plans for stronger nuclear cooperation are at the top of the agenda.
According to reports, India also hopes for a defense cooperation agreement between the two nations.
Police in Karratha arrest 20-year-old after high-speed motorcycle chase.
A motorcycle was seized after the driver rode it at 125 km/h in a 70 km/h zone and through bushland to escape police in Bilbara.
Traffic police in Karratha attempted to stop a blue motorcycle this morning after observing it leaving a gas station on Bathdate Road at 125 km/h.
Police report that the driver then ignored the stop signals and continued driving on Burgess Road before turning into bushland, where officers lost sight of it.
The motorcycle and a person matching the description of the rider were later seen at a house on Walcott Way in Bulgarra.
Karratha police have charged a 20-year-old man with failing to stop at a stop sign and reckless driving.
He is due to appear before the Magistrates Court in Karratha on September 23.
The motorcycle was secured and confiscated for three months.
George Webster charged with hotel rapes in Nairn and Pitlochry.
A man is on trial for raping women in two hotels.
George Webster, 28, had the charges read to him at a hearing at the High Court in Glasgow.
He is accused of raping a woman at Scotland's Hotel in Pitlochry, Perthshire, on June 7, 2013.
The charge states that Webster attacked her while she "was unconscious, sleeping, and unable to signal consent."
Webster is also accused of raping a second woman on May 4, 2014, at the Golf View Hotel in Nairn in the Scottish Highlands.
Judge Lady Rae set the hearing date for November 17 at the High Court in Edinburgh.
A return to the very American ideal of labor rights as human rights.
Representatives Keith Ellison and John Lewis have introduced a bill to establish labor union organizing as a civil right.
"As unions die, middle class jobs die too," said Ellison, a Democrat from Minnesota and deputy chair of the Progressive Caucus in Congress.
Therefore, I am proud to introduce the Employee Empowerment Act together with civil rights icon John Lewis.
This groundbreaking law gives workers the same legal options in cases of discrimination due to union organizing as with other forms of discrimination - and thus stops anti-union forces.

The amendment of the national labor law to create an opportunity for workers exposed to discrimination to organize union representation in order to sue for justice before a civil court - and to receive compensation or penalties - is a sensible and necessary initiative.
But it is certainly not a radical initiative - at least not by American standards.
Indeed, the best way to understand what Ellison, Lewis, and the other sponsors of their bill are proposing is to connect it back to a very American idea.

Despite the setbacks that unions have faced in recent years - in Wisconsin, Michigan and other states across the country - Americans once encouraged countries around the world to recognize, expand and uphold labor rights.
There was a time, which millions of Americans still remember, when this country mentioned democracy, freedom of speech, freedom of the press, and the right of assembly in the same breath.

When the United States occupied Japan after World War II, General Douglas MacArthur and his staff encouraged the country to adopt a constitution that would ensure that Hideki Tojo's militarized autocracy would be replaced by democracy.

Fully aware that workers and their unions played a role in creating a new Japan, they used language that explicitly acknowledged that "workers' rights to unite and to bargain and act collectively are guaranteed."

When the United States occupied Germany after World War II, General Dwight David Eisenhower and his staff urged the Germans to write a constitution that would ensure that Adolf Hitler's fascism would be replaced by a strong democracy.

In recognition of the fact that workers would need to organize themselves and raise their voice in the new nation, the Germans inserted a clause that explicitly stated: "The right to form associations to secure and improve working and economic conditions is guaranteed to every individual and to every occupation or trade."
Agreements that restrict or aim to diminish this right are null and void; measures aimed at this are illegal.

When former First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt chaired the International Human Rights Commission, which drafted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights as adopted by the United Nations as a worldwide agreement in 1948, Roosevelt and the other authors included a guarantee that "everyone has the right to form and join trade unions for the protection of their interests."
For generations, Americans have accepted the basic premise that labor rights are human rights.

When this country advised other countries on how to form civil and democratic societies, Americans explained that the right to form a union - and for that union to then participate in collective bargaining as an equal partner with companies and government agencies - must be protected.

After these rights came under attack in America, it is indeed very wise to recall the American ideal that the working population must have the right to unite and make their voices heard in a free and open society.
As Pastor Martin Luther King Jr. said fifty years ago:
History is a great teacher.
Now everyone knows that the labor movement did not limit the strength of the nation, but increased it.
By raising the standard of living for millions of people, labor has miraculously created a market for industry and lifted the entire nation to unimaginable levels of production.
Those who attack work forget these simple truths, but history preserves them.
History remembers, and so should we.
The formal recognition of labor rights as human rights - and the extension of civil rights protection as protection against discrimination in the creation of worker representations - is long overdue.
Keith Ellison and John Lewis renew the ideals that made America great in the past and fulfilled the promise of democracy.
Judge temporarily blocks law that could force all abortion clinics in Louisiana to close.
A US federal judge temporarily blocked the implementation of a law in Louisiana on Sunday that lawyers say would likely have led to the closure of all five abortion clinics in the state.

This measure, which was signed into law by Bobby Jindal, Governor of Louisiana, in June and is set to take effect on Sept. 1, would force doctors who perform abortions to obtain admitting privileges at a hospital within a 30-mile radius of their practice.
The judge's decision means, however, that doctors can temporarily continue to perform abortions legally while they apply for such a right.
"The plaintiffs can continue to work in compliance with the law while they pursue obtaining these rights," wrote Federal Judge John deGravelles in his ruling.
Within a month, a hearing will be scheduled for the judge to reach a more permanent decision on the law.
Abortion rights supporters welcomed the decision, the latest in a series of rulings against similar measures, and said that doctors would gain more time to obtain hospital admission rights.

"Today's decision means that women in Louisiana escape an insidious law that wants to take away their health and their rights," said Nancy Northup, president and chairwoman of the Center for Reproductive Rights, which had sued on behalf of three of the state's five clinics to stop the law.
It was not immediately clear whether the ruling also extended to the doctors from the two clinics who had not joined the lawsuit and had also applied for admission rights.
Louisiana is one of 11 states that have passed similar laws, with courts recently declaring such measures unconstitutional in Alabama and Mississippi.
Key provisions of a Texas law that would have forced most of the state's remaining clinics to close were blocked by a federal judge on Friday.

Abortion advocates and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists as well as the American Medical Association unanimously say that physician admitting privileges require unnecessary restrictions.
Abortion opponents counter that the measures serve to protect women's health, although some also welcomed the effects of clinic closures.
Only one doctor who performs abortions in Louisiana has hospital admitting privileges, according to the Center for Reproductive Rights.
If all other doctors in the state are forced to stop performing abortions, this doctor would no longer perform the operation out of fear for his safety, the group said.

In their argument against the ruling, representatives of the state of Louisiana said they would not punish doctors for performing abortions while their applications for hospital admitting privileges were still pending.
Delayed diagnoses and lack of access to the best treatment options lead to higher death rates from ovarian cancer in rural areas.
Angelina Jolie and her brother James posted a video tribute online for their mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 2007.
Women in rural areas of Australia have a higher risk of dying from ovarian cancer than women in cities.
Researchers analyzed the medical data of more than 1100 Australian women who were diagnosed with ovarian cancer in 2005, and found that only 25 percent were still alive five years after diagnosis.

Research leader Susan Jordan from the QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute said that for those living in rural and remote regions of the state, the mortality risk during the study was 20 percent higher than for those in urban areas.
SMALL STUDY: New drugs could slow down lung and ovarian cancer.
The researchers examined the medical care of women over seven years.
Dr. Jordan said that a woman's age at diagnosis, the type of ovarian cancer, existing pre-existing conditions, as well as social and economic status also influenced survival chances.
For older women and those whose cancer was already more advanced at the time of diagnosis, the survival rate was lowest.
For those who lived in rural and remote regions of the state, the mortality risk during the study was 20 percent higher than for those in urban areas.

Although the study did not investigate why women living outside the city were more likely to die from ovarian cancer, Dr. Jordan suspects delayed diagnosis and lack of access to the best treatment centers as possible factors.
"This disease is best treated by gynecologic oncologists, and they are usually found in larger cities," she said.

Despite the improvement of telemedicine services to counter the distances, she proposed as a possible remedy an enhancement of the service of fly-in doctors to give specialists the opportunity to provide care for women closer to their place of residence, as well as treatment programs for people outside their region.

Dr. Jordan said that regardless of geographical status, the study showed poor long-term survival rates in women with ovarian cancer and emphasized the need for better treatment and prevention strategies.
The study funded by Rio Tinto Ride to Conquer Cancer is published today in the Medical Journal of Australia.
In March 2013, Elisha Neave, a young 33-year-old mother from the Gold Coast, learned that she had an aggressive form of ovarian cancer.
Garden centers regret declining homeownership numbers.

The decline, along with an increased drop in the number of homeowners under 35, could lead to garden centers losing tens of thousands of pounds per year when today's young consumers reach the "core age group for garden products," according to a study by the HTA, as reported in the Financial Times.
The report states that renters spend on average 55 percent of the amount that homeowners spend on their garden.

The increase in people living in highly urbanized areas without gardens, the popular practice of paving front gardens for parking purposes, and the decreasing garden size are additional factors threatening the industry, which generates an estimated £5 billion in annual sales.
In the Greater London area, where the proportion of homeowners has fallen from 61 to 43 percent over a period of 6 years, the lowest expenditure on garden products per household is reported.
The HTA and the Royal Horticultural Society point out that living in rented accommodation or having small gardens does not mean that people cannot grow plants.
Guy Barter, chief gardening advisor for the RHS, said: "Container gardening is very popular with renters, for example, because they can take their plants with them when they move."
The HTA report identified the period between 1997 and 2005 as the "golden age" of garden retail due to rising homeownership numbers and economic prosperity from the late 1980s to the mid-1990s.
He also predicted an improved market situation for this year due to better weather following unfavorable weather conditions in March and April of last year.
The protest movement in Pakistan, led by opposition politician Imran Khan and cleric Tahirul Qadri, continues.
In the capital Islamabad, around 1000 protesters stormed the state television broadcaster PTV.
Information Minister Pervaiz Rashid said that soldiers were able to push the protesters back out of the PTV building.
The broadcaster suspended its operations for about 40 minutes but is now broadcasting again.
At the same time, around 3000 protesters tried to reach Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's residence.
About one kilometer away, armed with sticks and stones, they clashed with security forces.
The police used tear gas.
The protesters demanded Sharif's resignation, but he refuses it.
The country's army meanwhile urges a political solution to the conflict "without wasting time and without using violence."
After a meeting at headquarters on Sunday evening, the military announced: "The army remains committed to its role of ensuring the security of the state."
The military plays an important role in Pakistan and has staged coups frequently in the past.
Opposition politician Imran Khan accuses Prime Minister Sharif of cheating in the parliamentary elections last May.
The protests escalated over the weekend after Khan and Qadri called on their supporters to advance on Sharif's residence.
Three people were killed in the process.
Turkey summons US diplomat over espionage report
The Turkish Foreign Ministry has summoned the most senior US diplomat in the country to provide information about a report on American and British espionage in Turkey.
Deputy Prime Minister Bülent said that the US Embassy's chargé d'affaires and Turkish officials had discussed the report on Monday.

The German magazine Der Spiegel and the online magazine The Intercept reported that documents from former US National Security Agency analyst Edward Snowden show that Turkey was a major area of operations for US and British intelligence services.
According to Turkish news agencies, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan downplayed the importance of the report and said that all major countries spy on each other.
An earlier report that Germany's main intelligence service also had Ankara in its sights caused significantly more angry reactions from the Turkish government.
Strike warning: Train drivers threaten consequences for commuters
The nationwide warning strike by train drivers on Monday evening could also affect passenger transport in North Rhine-Westphalia.
The strike announced for 6 PM to 9 PM affects all transport companies nationwide, including long-distance, regional, and suburban train services.
The main thrust of the warning strike is freight transport.
Photo: A. Burgi/Archive
said Sven Schmitte, the district chairman of the German Train Drivers' Union (GDL), in Düsseldorf.
We expect significant disruptions.
There are no regional focal points.
The main thrust of the warning strike is directed at freight transport.
Deutsche Bahn in North Rhine-Westphalia announced that they would do everything to keep the impact as minimal as possible.
The GDL has not said where they intend to strike, making it difficult to predict the specific consequences.
Police chief of Magaluf charged with corruption
The prosecutors presented evidence of extortion by police officers and employees of the city of Calvià to the Mallorca prosecutor's office on Friday.
The police chief of Calvià on the holiday island of Mallorca was arrested following corruption allegations from business owners and bar owners in the notorious binge-drinking hotspot Magaluf.

Chief Inspector José Antonio Navarro was taken into custody following corruption allegations made against him by several business owners from Punta Ballena, the street where most of Magaluf's bars and nightclubs are located.

According to the online daily newspaper Mallorca Diario, prosecutors presented evidence of extortion by police officers and employees of the city of Calvià to the office of Mallorca's anti-corruption prosecutor on Friday.
Two more local police officers were arrested by the Spanish Guardia Civil in connection with corruption allegations and are being questioned by a judge together with Navarro.
The national Spanish newspaper ABC reported that angry nightclub owners stated that the authorities' nepotism had serious effects on their businesses.
"It's no longer about making money, it's about survival," one of the businessmen told the court.
Leave our livelihood out of it.
We have nothing to lose.
Magaluf made international headlines this summer due to a viral YouTube video showing an 18-year-old British tourist performing fellatio on 24 men during a pub crawl.
Since then, the island authorities have tried to stop the disorderly behavior of intoxicated tourists in Magaluf by minimizing the number of participants in the notorious alcohol-fueled pub crawls.
The Playhouse Club, where the fellatio incident took place, was forced to close for one year, while Playhouse and pub crawl organizer Carnage must jointly pay a fine of €55,000 ($73,000).

The tourist resort of Magaluf, which is particularly popular with young British holidaymakers, is also known for numerous accidents under the influence of alcohol, including the trend of "balconing," where people jump from one balcony to another or from a balcony into the hotel pool.
The first day of spring with wet and stormy weather conditions affects flights from Adelaide Airport.
Spring brought a wintry surprise to South Australia, with heavy showers and strong winds affecting flights from Adelaide Airport.
In the evening until 9 PM, another 5mm of rain fell on the city, following 6.6mm that had already fallen during the night before Sunday.
The last precipitation was the result of a series of short, stormy showers, including a downpour that began shortly before 8 PM and produced almost 4mm of rainfall in about 10 minutes.
After winter provided an early dose of spring last week, temperatures in the city dropped again on Monday to a high of only 15.8°C.
The gusty weather conditions likely led to the delayed landing of a Virgin Airlines flight from Melbourne to Adelaide.
The plane was supposed to land shortly after 7:30 PM but was hit by a wind shear - a sudden change in wind speed or direction over a short distance - and had to abort the landing.
Wind gusts reached approximately 50 km/h at ground level at Adelaide Airport.
The flight data showed that the aircraft had to abort a second landing attempt and finally touched down at around 8:40 PM.
The flight delay subsequently led to delays of several other flights, including an Emirates flight from Dubai and a Qantas flight from Sydney.
A maximum temperature of 16°C is forecast for Adelaide on Tuesday, with possible showers.
Matthies says: High time for major networking.

Given the galloping technical progress that threatens to transform our cozy homes into high-tech control centers, our columnist Bernd Matthies consoles himself with a very familiar electronic accessory.
While I'm writing this, my eyes fall on the coiled cord connecting the handset to the telephone, and I think: Wow, how retro is that?
But there's a thought behind it: If it weren't for the cable, all headphones would be flying around the house without an owner in no time, and that would be even more retro.

The text fragment appears incomplete and contains a made-up word "ekeltronischen" (which seems to be a play on "elektronischen" meaning electronic). Without the complete sentence, I cannot provide an accurate translation.
No, typing error: in the electronic sector, the rule is that today's world novelty is tomorrow's electronic waste, bought - outdated.
And whoever still has a tube TV in their living room today is merely saying that they fundamentally reject television.
Why these considerations?
Because the crowding at the Ifa at the Radio Tower this week once again demonstrates our absolute incompetence in matters of electronics..

The layman, who previously mastered washing machines and CD players blindly, today doesn't even understand the purpose of devices that are laid out before him with incredibly vain expert jargon: "Connected Home, Wearables, Health Care and Urban Technologies" promises the press office.
Are you kidding me?
What is there to talk about with people who apparently voluntarily spread such nonsense?
Basically, for about 20 years now, it's mainly been about how we should network our homes.
So that the yogurt reorders itself, so that the fire alarm tells us while we're on vacation in the Maldives that there's a fire in the study..
And wouldn't it be wonderful if we could set the air conditioning from the office for our upcoming arrival...?
Yes, but that requires an air conditioning system.
But one dream will definitely come true soon: We lift our wristwatch, loudly say "Vacuum!" - and at home the robot vacuum cleaner starts moving.
Crazy..

Everything is leading to nothing less than a revolution: "The boundaries between white and brown goods are blurring," whispers an industry expert - you can connect the washing machine to headphones, the steam cooker sends the weather report, and the data glasses show how long the pizza still needs in the oven, which is useless though because we're stuck in traffic.
From daily experience, we also know: When a modern device is really urgently needed, the battery is guaranteed to be empty.
This is another reason why the spiral cable on the telephone will survive the next radio exhibitions as well.
Israeli children return to their schools after the war in Gaza.

Thousands of Israeli children from areas near the Gaza Strip returned to school on Monday after spending the summer in bomb shelters while rocket and mortar fire rained down on their communities during the 50-day war between Israel and Hamas, and schools in Gaza remained closed as the area recovered from the fighting.
The start of school brought a feeling of joy and anticipation to the communities in southern Israel marked by rocket impact holes, but the signs of fighting are still fresh.
In the southern city of Ashdod, staff members of the "Pashosh" kindergarten, which was hit by a rocket, removed shrapnel from the walls and sliding walls before the students arrived.
"We are a bit scared, but excited," said Ronit Bart, resident of Kibbutz Saad and English teacher there.
Many children from our area urgently need to return to a routine.
Her 11-year-old daughter Shani Bart said it feels "a bit strange" to suddenly go back to school.
"Those were difficult times, and we didn't leave the house at all," she said.
President Reuven Rivlin visited the kibbutz near the Gaza border to offer his support.

Until a ceasefire interrupted the war last week, thousands of residents of border communities like Saad remained in their homes or left their houses to move to safer areas further away from Gaza to escape rocket and mortar fire.
Many residents of Nahal Oz, a community near the Gaza border where a 4-year-old boy was killed by a Palestinian mortar shell, are still hesitant to return.
The Ministry of Education announced that about a dozen families had not yet returned.
Their children were temporarily placed in other schools.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu visited a school in Sderot, a border town to Gaza that has been heavily affected by Palestinian shelling.
He appealed to the children to study hard and said "we will ensure that you acquire knowledge and provide you with security."
Israel and Hamas agreed to an open-ended ceasefire last Tuesday.

The ceasefire led to an immediate end of the fighting; however, important issues remain unresolved, such as Hamas' demand for lifting the Israeli-Egyptian blockade of Gaza and the reopening of Gaza's air and seaports.
Israel demands the disarmament of Hamas and the handover of the bodies of two Israeli soldiers killed in the fighting.
A new round of indirect talks is expected to begin in Egypt later this month.
In the war, more than 2,100 Palestinians were killed, three quarters of them civilians, and at least 494 children according to estimates by Palestinians and the UN.
Israel disputes these figures and estimates that at least half of those killed were fighters, but did not provide concrete evidence for this information.
On the Israeli side, 66 soldiers and six civilians, including a Thai worker, were killed.
Hamas and other fighters in Gaza fired 4,591 rockets and mortar shells at Israeli cities during the fighting, most of them in the south of the country.
Meanwhile, the Israeli military carried out more than 5,000 air and other attacks.
The Israeli attacks damaged or destroyed thousands of homes in the Gaza area, and about 250,000 people sought refuge in more than 100 UN schools that were converted into temporary shelters.
While tens of thousands of people continue to live in shelters and fighting continues, education authorities postponed the start of the school year last week.

"I hope the school will open again soon so that we can continue learning, just like the children in the world and the Jewish children," said Mohammad Amara, a 13-year-old boy who currently lives in a school in Gaza City.
After election in Saxony: CDU deputy Strobl questions NPD ban proceedings
In view of the NPD's loss of votes in Saxony, CDU Deputy Federal Chairman Thomas Strobl has called for an end to the ongoing NPD ban proceedings before the Federal Constitutional Court.
Berlin - According to CDU Federal Deputy Thomas Strobl, the ongoing prohibition proceedings against the NPD before the Federal Constitutional Court should come to an end.
"The NPD performs worse than last time," Strobl, who is also the CDU state leader in Baden-Württemberg, told the "Leipziger Volkszeitung."
This is a positive development in the right direction and a development that leads me to conclude that the NPD should be fought politically rather than in the Constitutional Court.
The NPD narrowly failed to clear the five percent threshold in Sunday's vote.
An initial attempt to ban the far-right party failed in 2003 because the Office for the Protection of the Constitution had informants in the NPD leadership at the time.
In December 2013, after long preparation, the Federal Council submitted a new application in Karlsruhe.
The Federal Government and Parliament did not join in.
Harburg: Tents for new refugees
Refugees are now being housed in tents at Neuländer Platz.
The central initial reception center for refugees in Harburg is bursting at the seams.
Now the interior authority has had three Red Cross tents set up next to it.
The district politicians were only informed shortly before - they are not very enthusiastic.

"These rushed actions further fuel citizens' reservations and give district politicians no opportunity to constructively participate in the humane accommodation of refugees," says Britta Herrmann, Green Party faction leader in the Harburg district assembly.
Their party demands that the Harburg district administration provide currently unused houses for accommodation.
96 refugees can be accommodated in the three tents.
Reasons for overcrowding in the initial reception center are the influx of people seeking help - and the fact that authorities cannot provide enough places in follow-up facilities.
Many refugees therefore stay longer than the regular three months.
House prices have experienced their strongest winter increase in seven years, shows a widely monitored index.
The RP Data CoreLogic Hedonic Home Value Index for owner-occupied homes in the Australian capital rose by 1.1 percent in August, according to RP data released on Monday.
Due to this increase, the total increase in June, July and August is 4.2 percent, the largest increase in the winter months since 2007.
The annual price increase was 10.9 percent, more than twice as high as the increase in the 12 months until August 2013, but the increases were not evenly distributed across the country.
The research director of RP Data, Tim Lawless, reported that Sydney and Melbourne are driving a two-tier market.
The figures from RP Data show that house prices in Sydney rose by 16.1 percent last year, while in Melbourne they increased by 11.7 percent.
The following markets are Adelaide, Brisbane and Darwin, where prices increased by an average of five to six percent.
At the other end of the scale is Canberra, which was hit hard by cuts in government spending and where prices rose by only 1.4 percent over the year.
Mr. Lawless further stated that with the beginning of spring, an increase in properties for sale would be observed over the next few months, which would subject the market to "a real test."

"When looking at the consistently high rate of auction prices, a generally fast sales rate, and the persistently low interest rate environment, it is likely that home prices will continue to rise over the next three months," he said.
In a statement to the Neue Presse, he contradicts statements made by managing director Peer Medau and attests that he is "posing like a field marshal."
This is not the style of the university, according to the statement.
The Medau family had already been "verbally informed about the university's request in mid-June."
"The statement that the plans only became known in July is definitely false," says Pötzl.
At the same time, he points out that these plans are not "preliminary determinations or even decisions," though there are "preferences."
The necessary expansion of the narrow road leading up to the castle, required for access, is less dramatic than feared by the Medaus.
There was and is no mention of a nine-meter-wide street.

The argument made by the Medau operators, that their free and school-owned parking spaces would then only be used by university students in the future, is not accepted by Pötzl.
There is no problem with blocked parking spaces at all, because this can now be solved intelligently, just like with other public parking spaces.
Think of the residents.

According to the university president, the Bergwichtel daycare center, which is located on the premises and in front of whose doorstep the access road to the parking deck would run, "will not be affected."

Rather, he points out "that this is not just about the daycare center, but also about the residents at the junction to Friedrich-Streib Street and the 800 students of the neighboring secondary school."

The reader can decide for themselves whether the criticism from the daycare center's parents' council, that the road expansion would result in "the loss of one of Coburg's few remaining natural spots," is justified.

Last week, Peer Medau informed the parents of the daycare center about the university's plans.
According to this, access to the new parking deck should not be via the campus and Friedrich-Streib-Straße as before, but via Medau-Berg.
This would require the narrow road to be expanded to two lanes over a length of about one kilometer.
According to projections by the Medaus, traffic in Hohenfels Castle park would increase tenfold.
There is talk of about 2000 vehicles daily.
The city authorities have so far refused to comment on the project.
Glandorf retires from handball national team.
Holger Glandorf will no longer play for the DHB team.
The 31-year-old from Bundesliga club SG Flensburg-Handewitt cited mainly health problems as the reason for this decision.
The decision wasn't easy for me; it matured over several months.
"It's time for me to listen to the signals of my body and end my career in the national team," the 2007 world champion shared on his Facebook page.
He thus retires from international duty with a record of 167 international matches and 576 goals for Germany.

Because the powerful backcourt player wants to continue scoring goals for Champions League winner Flensburg for several more years, he is no longer available for new national team coach Dagur Sigurdsson.
With the Icelander, who will announce his squad for the international matches against Switzerland on Tuesday, Glandorf had a "long and good conversation."
His ideas and approaches inspired me just as much as they will inspire my long-time fellow players and my successors.
But I also want to be available for my club in good health in the coming years, which requires longer recovery breaks that the current double workload does not allow.
The left-hander had even feared the end of his career in 2012 after a heel infection.
Due to Achilles tendon problems, he had received a cortisone injection from team doctors of the German Handball Federation (DHB), which later triggered a severe inflammation.
An emergency operation and two additional procedures followed.
Then Glandorf had announced a lawsuit against the team doctor, the dispute ended with a settlement.
Twelve years of professional career and eleven years with the national team don't pass without leaving their mark on any body.
I have some health issues that I can no longer ignore.
After the three infection-related foot surgeries that occurred in quick succession in 2012, I never really got my blood pressure under control.
This is accompanied by several other wear-related complaints.
"Already at the beginning of the year, I noticed that while I could control my mind, I couldn't deceive my body," Glandorf explained in an interview with "Handball Time" magazine.
He would only be available for a comeback in an absolute emergency.
"If all else fails, I'm always ready to talk," the father of two explained to the trade magazine.
However, I can count the years I can still play handball on one hand.
I must also say that after my long hospital stay in 2012, I have become quite humble when it comes to my health.
After my career, I would at least like to be able to walk somewhat straight.
In addition to the 2007 World Championship title and winning the Champions League in 2014, he won the EHF Cup in 2008 (HSG Nordhorn) and 2010 (TBV Lemgo).
In 2012, he also won the European Cup Winners' Cup with Flensburg.
German economy contracted by 0.2 percent in spring
Global crises have slowed down the German economy in the second quarter.
Gross domestic product fell by 0.2 percent from April to the end of June 2014 compared to the previous quarter.
The Federal Statistical Office announced this, confirming preliminary calculations.
Consumer spending alone boosted the economy in spring, while investments declined.
Foreign trade also slowed down the economy.
Thanks to the strong start to the year, overall GDP growth for the first half of the year was 0.8 percent compared to the second half of 2013.
Horstmar was the starting point and destination of the "Münsterland-Mooiste," which led through the Burgmann city for the first time on Sunday.
The castle town of Horstmar experienced an invasion of Dutch cyclists on Sunday.
The largest cycling association in the Netherlands, NTFU, organized the so-called "Münsterland's Most Beautiful"
This is the biggest bicycle tour across Münsterland, the cycling paradise near the Netherlands.
More than 1000 participants expressed their gratitude to Jos ter Huerne for organizing this tour through Münsterland by registering.
This tour was offered to interested parties through advertisements in various trade journals.
We come from Den Helder and drove overnight to participate in this tour.
We would like to get to know the Münsterland region better in this way too," the cyclists were happy about the route through the districts of Steinfurt, Borken and Coesfeld.
After registering at the clubhouse of the St. Marksmen's Brotherhood
Katharina went on a small "peace ride" through the city along the wall, where the start also took place.
The route, which was designated for three different categories, continued towards Herrenholz over the Schöppinger Berg in the direction of Coesfeld and back to Horstmar via Havixbeck and Billerbeck.

On routes of 95 kilometers with 1175 meters of elevation gain, 120 kilometers with 1475 meters of elevation gain, and 145 kilometers with 1775 meters of elevation gain, the cyclists proved their good fitness.
They were provided with food and supplies along the way in Havixbeck and Billerbeck.
Main organizer Jos ter Huerne and deputy mayor Heinz Lölfing were very pleased with the success of this cycling event.
We are satisfied and it was a wonderful experience for everyone involved.
The organization went smoothly and there were no negative incidents," Heinz Lölfing draws a positive conclusion from this event.
Unfortunately, not as many participants showed up as the organizer had hoped for, which was probably due to the bad weather forecast and the morning rain.

"We'll see each other again in 2015, hopefully with nice weather on August 30th or during another weekend," the cyclists promised to return to Münsterland nevertheless, and the organizers are planning a new edition.
Konstantin Wecker's brutally honest memoirs.

It is actually more of a philosophical testimony than a biography that Konstantin Wecker - singer-songwriter, pacifist, political activist, ex-prisoner - has put to paper in "Monk and Warrior" across 287 pages.

The Munich-born author, who was born on June 1, 1947, wrote his memoirs not chronologically but rather as fragments of thoughts following fragments of thoughts, with each chapter introduced by a fitting song lyric.
And he is brutally honest about it: From masturbation as a high school student to shoplifting and drug use, he leaves out no human weakness.
Also, to show how he himself learned tolerance in dealing with his fellow human beings.

Abstract but all the more important concepts also take up considerable space: love, soul, ego, being in the present, spirituality - he tries to get to the bottom of all of this in a very philosophical but also very personal way.

And he also explains his pacifism, his social criticism, his political engagement - and also how he was shaped not only by music (the opera lover became a soul and rock musician) but also by his time in prison.
The latter has also brought the bon vivant Konstantin Wecker closer to the ascetic monk, who "emerges through subtraction," as he says, "by removing everything unnecessary."
Among all the intellectual views, there are also brief anecdotes to keep things grounded: for instance, about fights in a bar frequented by GIs or a crazy car ride where he aimed straight at a tree.
He is brutally honest there as well.
Lenny Henry: My father never hugged me.
Never said "I love you"
Henry was one of seven children in a family of Jamaican immigrants in Dudley in the Midlands in 1958.
His father, who died when Henry was 19, worked in a factory and their relationship was limited.
Henry is rehearsing for a comedy, Rudy's Rare Records, which is partly based on an imaginary conversation with his father and originated from the Radio 4 series.
The soundtrack is a mixture of reggae and rap, with lively melodies.
But Henry had to work through some difficult childhood moments.
He attended "many" therapy sessions after his mother's death, and Henry is thoughtful about his relationship with his father.
It was difficult to know him.
You never saw his face, only heard his voice: "Stop making that noise."
Leave your sister alone.
Move!
I want to watch cricket.

My older brothers Seymour and Hilton - who were already adults when I was a child - went to the pub with him and talked about things like the shape of the beer glass or the beauty of a cricket stroke.
I never had such a conversation with him.
For most of my life, he was that serious guy in the corner reading the newspaper.
Recently, Henry opened a foundry in Dudley, and although the conditions are better than in his father's time, he gained insight into what life might have been like for him.
It is somewhat brighter now, but they are dark, smoky, deep stygian labyrinths with bursts of flame and smoke and lots of soot.
My father used to simply lie down in the bathtub, and then you could slowly hear him start to sing because he could wash the foundry off himself.
As I walked around there, I realized that he had done this for years to put food on the table, and my respect for him grew.
Nevertheless, Henry grew up as a child without expressions of love from his parents.
My father never hugged me, he never said "I love you"
Only when my mother was doing poorly toward the end of her life did we start saying "I love you, I love you, I love you."
Through his own daughter Billie, with Dawn French, he was able to share the love that he had missed as a child.
Could you stop with the "I love you"?
Stop hugging me!
Dad, I'm 22!
with Dawn French
Why shouldn't we be friends?
She is a great mother.
He is still friends with French, to whom he was married for 25 years.
Dawn is a good person.
Why shouldn't we be friends?
She is a great mother.
Henry's own mother was diabetic.
That contributed to her death.
When I became very, very overweight and showed symptoms of diabetes, my doctor said "You need to be radical."
So I went through with this fitness thing and also had to go on a drastic diet to reverse the symptoms.
It is very difficult..
And it is exhausting..
Nobody likes to eat carrots.
Henry's career change is perhaps reflected in his elegant, closely trimmed beard.
Since he was praised by critics for his Othello, he has been consumed by the theater.
The Comedy of Errors followed, and then Fences by August Wilson.
This is a different experience than the sitcoms and comedies that filled his busy working life.
He started at just 16 years old when he worked in a factory.
A DJ discovered him on stage when he was imitating people and wrote to New Faces about him.
His television career began in the mid-seventies. "For quite a long time, I was the only black impersonator/comedian on television."
He learned on the job.
I not only had to grow up in the public eye, but also had to learn from 1975 to 1985 how to become an efficient joke-telling machine while being a TV star, and that was really difficult.
Lenny 1975 at New Faces
Since his manager owned the stage rights to the Black and White Minstrel Show, a light entertainment program where people performed in blackface, Henry performed his comedy there for five years.
My family was very uncomfortable with that.
Somehow I wish it had never happened, but I don't regret that I did it.
It was a strange, uncomfortable position for me, but I worked on huge projects and learned how to deal with a large audience.
But this "years-long award-winning light pillar of British television" was also a "grotesque parody of black people."
Through the introduction of characters who both mocked and celebrated British black culture, Henry worked in an alternative comedy circuit in the 1980s.
The first series of the Lenny Henry Show aired in 1984, and in the nineties he was known among other roles as head chef Gareth Blacklock in the comedy series Chef!

Commercials, documentaries, TV series and film roles shaped his next decade, but after his BBC series LennyHenry.tv in 2008, he thought to himself: "What are you going to do next, Len, because it all feels like you're just killing time or treading water a bit."
After that came a documentary series for Radio 4 titled What's So Great About ...?
The first episode revolved around Shakespeare.
I was downright allergic to Shakespeare.
I never really learned anything about him in school and mostly considered him a domain of the middle class, white people in tights with a cabbage head in the front.
So I was very afraid of it.
Everyone we interviewed for the show - Peter Hall, Trevor Nunn, Adrian Lester, Judi Dench - said "You should give it a try."
Don't criticize it if you don't know what you're talking about.
Take some of the words in your mouth, and then you will understand why we all love Shakespeare so much.
Henry performed 20 lines from Othello's final speech for the documentary and he was thrilled.
I had the feeling that I could do it.
It was almost as if someone had finally put my head on properly.
That's what it's about, it's a serious matter, take it seriously, learn your text, do some research..
The rehearsals were brutal, and I read this play for months before we did it.
And it was a success.
They seemed to be expecting a car accident, and it simply didn't happen.
And soon he appeared in The Comedy of Errors.
Suddenly I was in the National Theater and I could hardly believe it.
There was a moment when I thought, "Oh, you have changed."
There was a technical error and Henry instinctively felt that he had to entertain the audience.
A small voice told me "You need to bridge 10 minutes now while they repair the computer."
Instead, the stage manager announced that the performance would continue as soon as the problem was solved.
I walked off the stage and something inside me said "Oh, thank God."
I am not responsible for that.
I can leave that to someone else.
You're acting in a play, so stay in your role.
Henry in Fences at the Duchess Theatre
Learning the text for Fences was challenging.
Panic is very good, it strengthens the tendons.
This was also well received, so it's like a big sign from the gods telling me "This is your destiny."
He says this, of course, with a THUNDERING voice.
So I'll stick with it.
I really love that.
I love being in a rehearsal room.
However, Henry still has the mind of a comedian - our conversation is interspersed with humorous outbursts while he keeps imitating people.
I have decided not to do stand-up comedy because I find that this kind of instant gratification from a room full of strangers is somehow dangerous.
If you keep searching for that, you'll hit a wall.
I sometimes perform live at the Apollo when I feel like it, but overall it doesn't give me as much as it used to.
I ask him if he will ever do another stand-up comedy tour.
The fun I have in a room with a director who helps shape a beginning, middle, and end of a journey - I don't think I ever want to give that up again.
So this is his new incarnation?
I think so..
I like being an actor.
It's fun.
One always tells a story, and that is great.
I love stories.
People love stories.
Houthi rebels block roads in Yemen's capital.
In the conflict between Shiite Houthi rebels and the Yemeni government, the Houthis have called for civil disobedience in the capital Sanaa.
Houthi supporters occupied central streets in Sanaa on Monday, said a spokesman for the Houthi party "Ansar Allah".
Access to Parliament was also blocked.
Yemeni media report traffic chaos in the capital.
According to the online edition of the "Yemen Post" newspaper, Houthi leader Abdulmalik al-Houthi called for the measures on Sunday evening.
The Houthi threatened with a further escalation of the conflict if their demands were not met, according to the newspaper.
The Shiite Houthis are fighting for more independence from Sunni-ruled Yemen and demand the resignation of the government.
The Houthi tribe has been besieging the Yemeni capital for almost two weeks.
Around 30,000 rebels have set up protest camps along the major access roads to Sanaa.
In the surrounding area, there are repeated bloody clashes with the Yemeni army.
Kenya registers civil servants to curb "ghost employees"
Kenya has begun to biometrically register all civil servants in order to remove "ghost employees" from government payrolls.
Employees who do not register within the next two weeks will no longer be paid, according to a government announcement.
The government suspects that thousands of people continue to receive salary payments even after leaving public service.
President Uhuru Kenyatta promised to fight corruption in public service when he took office in 2013.
During an audit at the beginning of this year, it was discovered that at least $1 million (£700,000) per month was lost in payments to "ghost employees" and through other abusive financial practices.
The government suspects that salaries continue to be paid into accounts after a person has died or left public service, reports Wanyama Chebusiri for the BBC from the capital Nairobi.
All civil servants must now appear at identification centers within the next two weeks to ensure their data is captured through biometric registration, according to a government message.
All those who would not do this without a credible excuse would be removed from the payroll, the message continued.

"This approach significantly contributes to the rationalization of public service by determining the actual number of civil servants and cleaning up the payroll at both government levels - thus eliminating 'ghost employees,'" said Anne Waiguru, the Cabinet Secretary in the Ministry of Devolution and Planning.
The scandal surrounding art consultant Helge Achenbach will first be heard in court on November 11.

Five heirs of Berthold Albrecht, son of Aldi founder Theo Albrecht, are demanding 19.4 million euros in damages from Achenbach and two of his companies, which are in insolvency proceedings, in a civil lawsuit at the Düsseldorf Regional Court.
A court spokeswoman announced this on Monday.
According to the statement of claim, Achenbach committed fraud in the purchase of artworks and vintage cars and charged Berthold Albrecht higher prices than were actually paid.
This resulted in a higher agreed commission.
Achenbach had purchased valuables worth 121 million euros for Albrecht.
Children need roots and wings.
He spent 44 years in the school system, 23 of them as a principal.
From this time, Manfred Richter knows many established residents of Petershausen and Kollbach from their time as students.
His methods were sometimes unconventional, but always driven by his endeavor to see the human being in the student.
The Sniezka (Sněžka) is the most famous mountain of the Giant Mountains.
Manfred Richter loves the painting with the motif from his homeland.
Richter was born in 1930 in Trautenau/North Bohemia, today Trutnov.
At the age of 14, after four years of secondary school, he became interested in becoming a teacher.
One year later, the Sudeten Germans were expropriated.
Within half an hour, the family had to leave their house.
After several months in a camp, they went to Bavaria in 1946 - in a freight car.
This is how Richter ended up in Senkendorf in Upper Franconia.
Teacher training took place in Bamberg.

For this, Manfred Richter had to walk ten kilometers to the nearest train station six times per week, take the train to Bamberg, walk three kilometers across the entire city to school, and then back again in the evening.
After two months, Manfred Richter got a place to sleep in a Red Cross home in Bamberg: together with up to 15 classmates in a dormitory.
In 1951, he passed his first state examination and in 1954, after three years as a teacher trainee, he passed his second state examination.
Since Upper Franconia had no vacant teaching position for him, he applied to Upper Bavaria and came to the school in Kollbach on November 1, 1954.
The "Miss's Room" was his first "official apartment" in the schoolhouse.
In 1958, he moved into a three-room service apartment in the newly built teachers' house next to the school.
Manfred Richter bought this house in 1980 after the school in Kollbach was closed in 1968.
Until then, there were three classes in Kollbach in the Petershausen-Kollbach school district and five in Petershausen.
From the 1968/69 school year, these were consolidated in Petershausen in today's town hall.
When the Indersdorf School Association was founded, only the elementary school remained in the town.
To avoid a demotion in the now smaller school, the then principal Georg Sigl transferred to Karlsfeld - and Manfred Richter became his successor.
However, Petershausen grew, and so from September 1982 the children and their teachers were able to move into the current building, which was expanded in 1997 after Richter's retirement.

Manfred Richter praises the uncomplicated generosity of then-mayor Ludwig Götz, who had an additional workshop and basement rooms built at community expense during the 1997 expansion, although this was not eligible for subsidies according to school building guidelines.
"Mayor Götz was very supportive of schools," Richter gratefully recalled.

Throughout his entire career, Manfred Richter never forgot the speech contribution of a government representative who had responded to a school board member's presentation about law and justice: "One must never forget love". Manfred Richter implemented what he had heard there as a young teacher.
"You must give children two things: roots and wings," says the 84-year-old.
And he had to learn: "That doesn't always work." Whether he means only his students or equally his own six children is not entirely clear.
In any case, Richter's actions were sometimes unconventional.
When students got into fights, he didn't give them detention or make them stay after school.
At the expense of the community, Richter had purchased two pairs of boxing gloves and let the two opponents face each other, even if it might result in a black eye.
For the benefit of the school, as principal, Richter maintained a good relationship with the then-mayor Ludwig Götz (CSU).
This motivated the non-partisan judge, after his retirement, to run in 1996 at least as the last candidate on the CSU list for the municipal council.
However, Richter was pre-elected to sixth place and joined the CSU.
180 kilometers in three days
HR4 BIKE TOUR: 700 cyclists make intermediate stops at the spa gardens of Bad Salzhausen and Schotten.
When cyclists take a break in Bad Salzhausen or Schotten during their tour, that's nothing special in itself.

On Friday, however, the number of people taking a break alone made an impression: The 700 participants of the hr4 bike tour, along with their support crew, enjoyed a break in the lower spa gardens of Bad Salzhausen and later an open-air party in Schotten's Alteburg Park.
Under the motto "Cycling and celebrating on newly discovered paths between Nidda and Kinzig," participants met in Bad Vilbel on Thursday and experienced a concert by Van Baker & Band.
On Friday, things got serious: The cyclists tackled the first stage, covering 60 kilometers through Florstadt to Bad Salzhausen and on to Schotten.
In Bad Salzhausen, the athletes were welcomed by Mayor Hans-Peter Seum, who had started cycling in Bad Vilbel, and the head of the Bad Salzhausen municipal enterprise, Petra Schwing-Döring.

For the refreshment of body and mind, all sorts of good things had been prepared: The rural women from Ranstadt and Nieder-Mockstadt had baked 85 trays of apple, plum, crumble, and cheesecakes, which the diligent cyclists found delicious.
"Only country women can bake such cakes," praised a participant from Aulendiebach, while ordering another piece.
Cold refreshments could be purchased at the beverage stand of the Geiß-Nidda gymnastics club.
The "Duo Bravo" entertained visitors with well-known melodies from operettas and musicals and received enthusiastic applause.
The beautiful ambiance of the park had a relaxing effect.
A gentleman also enjoyed a head massage from his partner: "He deserved it, after all, he has already reattached fallen-off bicycle chains today."

Meanwhile, the mayor and the operations manager still had to work: They were interviewed by reporter Rainer Janke at the fountain in front of the drinking cure house and used the opportunity to promote Bad Salzhausen on the radio.
Promotion manager Tobias Hagen, who has been the tour leader since the first hr4 bike tour in 2004, could only catch his breath briefly, as he had plenty to do with the on-site technology.

His pickup truck, in which he communicated with his employees and the 15-member motorcycle squad of the Hessen police via three phones and a radio device, wrote Facebook posts and made reports, also needed a check.

"Most of the participants come from the Rhine-Main area," he said, "but cyclists have also traveled from Giessen or Fulda, from Lauterbach or the Taunus region, and even from numerous cities in Westphalia."
The number of participants depends somewhat on the available overnight accommodation capacity.
In category I, participants are accommodated in hotels, in category II in shared accommodations.
The cyclists had a good impression of the spa town when they set off again after an hour and a half: "Bye!"
"It was lovely in Bad Salzhausen!" they waved goodbye.
After arriving in Schotten, the group was allowed to take a short breather.
But in the evening, the cyclists were challenged in the idyllic Alteburg Park.

Under the direction of the Schotten Tourism and City Marketing Society (GTS), the park had received a beautiful festival atmosphere, and of course, delicacies such as tarte flambée with well-chilled Federweißer (young wine) had been prepared.
Mayor Susanne Schaab, GTS Managing Director Markus Hoßfeld, and MSC Chairman Wolfgang Wagner-Sachs in his role as board member of ADAC Hessen-Thüringen welcomed the visitors.
The three were visibly delighted about the "high activity in Schotten"
DJ Tobias Hagen then opened up the dance floor.
The opportunity for vigorous movement under the open sky was eagerly used despite the physical activity on the bicycle.
More and more locals mingled with the guests, who were just as impressed by the good atmosphere as the large group of cyclists.
On the second day, the cyclists' schedule included stops in Birstein, Wächtersbach and Bad Orb - including a concert with the Trenkwalders.
Yesterday, after cycling 180 kilometers, the athletes returned to Bad Vilbel.
Dozens of Turkish police officers arrested for "conspiracy" against the government
A total of 33 police officers were arrested in Turkey on suspicion of "conspiracy against the government," according to local media agencies.
The police authorities did not provide any immediate comment.
Among those arrested are 14 high-ranking police officers, reports Hürriyet Daily News.
Some of them were involved in corruption investigations against government officials, including four government ministers last December.
In July, a number of Turkish police officers were arrested for allegedly forming an organized criminal organization and tapping phone numbers.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan (who was Prime Minister at the time) described their actions as part of the activities led by the Islamist cleric Fethulla Gülen against him and other people in positions of power.
Not all children in Ukraine are returning to school.
Schools almost everywhere in Ukraine opened on Monday (September 1) after the summer holidays.
This day is traditionally an important day for families, and like thousands of other Ukrainian parents, Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk brought his daughter to school.
There he informed waiting journalists that not all schools had reopened, but that he was determined to defend the country for future generations.
The September celebrations were not held in every school.
The sky is not peaceful everywhere over Ukraine.
We must fight for peaceful skies.
The entire Ukraine, a huge united Ukrainian people's front must fight for peaceful skies.
Aleksan Pastukhow, principal of the school in Slavyansk that Yatsenyuk's daughter attends, spoke in Russian.
We hope that peace will finally reign here again and that the children will receive an education that will be useful to them in their future lives.
The first day of the new school year is traditionally celebrated, with children wearing embroidered shirts, holding balloons in their hands, and giving flowers to their teachers.
With Rona Fairhead, the BBC may have found the great director it needs.
She arrives with an impressive trail of glory from the banking world, media management, and the inner circle of the Tory Party.
And she has her own front-line experience.
Her career began at the global management consulting firm Bain and Co., after which she moved to Morgan Stanley, Bombardier, ICI and Pearson's media world.
She was CEO of the Financial Times for seven years and resigned when the top position at the parent company Pearson went to a younger male colleague.
Her severance payment was reportedly almost 1 million £.
Her political ranking is also solid.
She was recommended to David Cameron by Lord Browne, the former chairman of BP, when he was looking for more private sector expertise in Whitehall: she became an advisor to the Cabinet.
Her husband is a former Tory council member.
Already in May, I described the role of the chairman as a poisoned chalice.
Not only does the BBC stand as a huge and complex entity at the heart of public life, but there is also an internal paradox in its structure.
Trust works in two directions: internally towards the first tier of BBC's own management hierarchy, but also externally as a voice of public concern and unrest when things go wrong.
This creates an almost untenable duopoly that requires a complete comprehensive reform.

But which newly arriving chairman would risk taking office, striking out at everything and dismantling an institution that is as complex as a Chinese dynasty, while possibly losing his own job in the process.
It is a difficult task.
And as if that wasn't enough, many are also interested in seeing the BBC downsized - power, money and status outdated.
While competition draws closer and new technologies threaten old, comfortable certainties, the upcoming negotiation of license fees for the BBC is fraught with particular dangers.
For the modest sum of £145.50 per year, the British public buys into what is certainly the world's largest media company.
The BBC tells a good story: they say that they reach 96 percent of all households and cost each of them only 40 pence per day.
And apparently the BBC is rising again on the popularity scale: 53 percent support it today, compared to 31 percent 10 years ago.
Viewing and usage habits for the BBC have changed: These days I get news headlines on my phone and watch missed programs later on my iPlayer.
But it remains a very beloved and remarkable institution.
She needs a remarkable chairman - I hope she has found him.
Perry from Texas says derogatory tweet was not authorized.

A tweet from the official account of Republican Texas Governor Rick Perry on Sunday contained a disparaging remark about the Democratic district attorney who is at the center of a criminal indictment against him for abuse of power.
The tweet was later deleted and replaced by another one from Perry's account that denied the previous one.
A tweet was just sent from my account that was not authorized by me.
"I do not approve of the tweet and have deleted it," said the later message.
Perry's staff did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
Although the tweets came from Perry's official user account, it was not clear who actually operated the feed.
In the earlier tweet, an unfavorable picture was painted of Travis County District Attorney Rosemary Lehmberg, who was convicted of drunk driving in April 2013.

Perry vetoed funding for her office when she refused to resign, which led to an indictment against Perry - who could potentially be a 2016 presidential candidate - before a grand jury this month in Austin.
I don't always drive drunk with three times the legal alcohol limit... but when I do, I sue Governor Perry when he reveals it.
I am the drunkest Democrat in Texas.
Lehmberg's office was not in charge of the Grand Jury investigation against Perry.
This was led by Michael McCrum, a special prosecutor from San Antonio who was selected by a Republican judge.
Perry pleads not guilty and called the indictment a political trick.

His high-caliber team of legal counsels petitioned the judge assigned to the case to dismiss the charges, arguing that the law being used against the longest-serving governor in Texas state history is unconstitutionally vague.

Perry blocked $7.5 million in state funds for the Public Integrity Unit of the state - which is based in Travis County and investigates cases of state corruption in Texas - when Lehmberg refused to resign.
This veto led to a public complaint from a left-wing watchdog group.
Perry's official user account is frequently updated - and sometimes famous.

After finishing fifth in the Iowa caucuses during his 2012 presidential campaign, Perry addressed speculation that he would quit by posting a tweet with a photo of himself jogging near a lake, saying "South Carolina, here we come!"
Berkeley declares housing market "normal" again.
One of London's most prominent property developers pointed out that the housing market in South East England has "returned" to normal levels.

Residential properties in the capital were in high demand and subject to enormous price increases, which prompted the Bank of England to set mortgage lending limits in June due to widespread fears of a credit bubble.

Tony Pidgley, founder and CEO of the upscale construction company Berkeley, said on Monday: "Since the beginning of the current financial year, the market has returned to normal transaction levels since the peak in 2013" and added that this provided a "stable operating environment."
The real estate market in London was well positioned during the downturn as foreign buyers flocked to the capital.
According to information from the Land Registry, prices in the city area alone jumped by 18.5 percent in the past year, far more than the average increase across England and Wales overall.
The average sales prices for Berkeley's private, affordable and student offerings increased by approximately one-fifth over the past year and stood at around £423,000 at the end of April.

A stronger pound has made property in London less attractive to foreign buyers in recent months - some of them have also been deterred by the introduction of new property taxes and political rhetoric around a possible "mansion tax" ahead of the general election in May.

Last week, London real estate agent Foxtons warned that the April mortgage market report, which introduced stricter lending regulations, would also lead to lower market growth in both property sales and prices in the second half of the year.
New data from the Bank of England on Monday shows a decline in mortgage approvals in July, which also indicates that the real estate market is cooling down.
Hamptions International, another real estate agency, revised its forecast for London property price increases in 2015 downward to 3 percent, based on an already weakening house price sentiment.
Transaction volumes in London's most expensive areas such as Chelsea, Mayfair and Kensington have now declined by a quarter year on year, according to estate agent WA Ellis.
Nevertheless, the desire for home ownership in the capital is a blessing for Berkeley, as the amounts due for forward sales amount to more than £2.2 billion.
Mr Pidgley added: "Demand for the right, well-planned product in the best locations remained stable and as a result, forward sales have also remained stable."
In June, the company reported that it had sold 3,742 new homes in the year ending April - almost a third more than at the peak in 2007 before the crisis.
The annual pre-tax profit increased by 40 percent to £280 million, while revenue grew by 18 percent to £1.6 billion.
In a statement on Monday ahead of the company's annual meeting, Mr. Pidgley said that Berkeley's revenue for the current year would likely meet current market expectations.
Analysts unanimously estimate the annual pre-tax profit at £450 million.
Berkeley shares held steady at £23.96 in London afternoon trading.
Nude photos of Jennifer Lawrence published on the internet by hackers.
Jennifer Lawrence appearance at the 85th Academy Awards
Nude photos of Oscar winner Jennifer Lawrence were published online by a hacker who claimed to have a "master list" of images of 100 more starlets.
A representative of the star from "The Hunger Games" confirmed that the photos of Lawrence were genuine and accused the hacker of "flagrant violation of privacy."
The authorities have been notified and will pursue all those who continue to post the stolen photos of Jennifer Lawrence.

The photos, which were originally posted on the photo-sharing site 4chan, were allegedly obtained through a security breach in Apple's online storage system iCloud. The alleged "master list" of hacking victims includes the names of dozens of female stars, including Rihanna, Kim Kardashian, Mary Elizabeth Winstead and Mary-Kate Olsen, BuzzFeed reported.
It is not certain how many of the images are real, although Winstead, star of "Scott Pilgrim vs. the World," also condemned the hack on Twitter.
"To those of you who are looking at photos that my husband and I took years ago in the private setting of our home - I hope you're really satisfied with yourselves," Winstead wrote on Twitter.
Victoria Justice from the Nickelodeon series "iCarly" and "Victorious" denied that the photos were pictures of her and tweeted "These alleged nude photos of me are FAKE, people.."
Let's nip it in the bud. *Wordplay intended*
Buzzfeed reported late Sunday that a spokesperson for pop star Ariana Grande denied the authenticity of the alleged photos of her.
Exclusive excerpt from Howard Jacobson's highly acclaimed new novel about love and the letter "J"
They melted away, that was the best way to describe it, they slowly dissolved like a cardboard box left standing in the rain.
Occasionally, a woman would tell him that he was too serious, exhausting, intense, distant, and perhaps a bit gruff.
And then shook his hand.
He knew grumpy/cantankerous...
He was prickly, like a hedgehog, yes..
The last victim of this prickliness was a budding affair that had been more promising than usual for alleviating the lonely boredom of his life, and might have even brought him a certain contentment.
Ailinn Solomons was a tremblingly delicate beauty with untamed hair and a fluttering heart from a village on the North Island that was even more remote and rugged than Port Reuben.
She had come south with an elderly companion, whom Kevern thought to be her aunt, and who had inherited a property in a damp but paradisiacal valley with the fitting name Paradise Valley.
For several years, no one had lived in the house.

The pipes were leaking, there were still spiders in the bathrooms, slugs had left their traces on all windows and thought they owned everything, and the garden was overgrown with weeds that looked like giant cabbage heads.
It was like the house from a children's fairy tale, both threatening and alluring, a garden full of secrets.
Portrait of the author: Howard Jacobson, whose novel "J" is on the longlist for the 2014 Man Booker Prize.
The shortlist will be announced next week.

Kevern had sat holding hands with Ailinn on broken deck chairs in the tall grass, enjoying an unusually warm spring afternoon. Both had absentmindedly tuned into the service console that supplied the country with soothing music and calming news when the sight of their crossed brown legs reminded him of an old song by a long-forgotten black entertainer that his father used to listen to at home with the shutters closed.

Lesotho military member says no coup planned; Prime Minister remains in South Africa
Military officials in Lesotho denied planning a coup to overthrow the government and said they were taking action against police officers accused of arming political fanatics.
Prime Minister Thomas Thabane fled the country and reported that the country's army had surrounded his official residence and occupied government buildings in the capital Maseru.
The Prime Minister moved his family to neighboring South Africa after reporting assassination threats.
Military spokesman Major Ntlele Ntoi said that there was effectively no coup, but that the military was responding to the threat from "political fanatics" who were about to be armed by the police.

"What happened this morning was that the Defense Forces staff of Lesotho acted after receiving several intelligence reports that within the police, some elements were acting to actually arm some of the political, partisan young fanatics who were about to cause devastating damage," he told Voice of America.
The South African government spokesman Clayson Monyela said the military action gave the impression of a coup.
"Even though no one has claimed to have seized power by force, all reports agree that the activities of Lesotho's defense forces so far show signs of a coup," he said.
Military spokespeople from Lesotho announced on Sunday that the soldiers were withdrawing to their barracks and the situation in the capital was calm.
In the meantime, Deputy Prime Minister Mothetjoya Metsing takes over government leadership during Thabane's absence.
Thabane stated that he believes he became a target because of his attempt to fight corruption in the country.
In Lesotho, there have been major tensions since June, after Thabane suspended parliamentary sessions due to disputes within his unity government.
He said his actions had not undermined the government, despite claims to the contrary.
Production in the Eurozone at a 13-month low.
The increase in production in the Eurozone slowed in August to its lowest point in 13 months, according to a closely monitored study.
The final Markit Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 50.7 in August, down from 51.8 in July.
A value above 50 indicates expansion.
New orders declined and factories experienced slumps during a time of rising tensions between the EU and Russia over Ukraine.
The figures arrive ahead of the European Central Bank (ECB) meeting on Thursday.
Markets expect a clear plan from the bank on how to deal with a hesitant recovery of the Eurozone as well as the looming deflation with an inflation rate of only 0.3%.

There are speculations that ECB President Mario Draghi could provide further information this week about whether he is considering quantitative easing for the Eurozone, similar to that implemented by Great Britain and the USA during the financial crisis.

"Although small growth is better than no growth at all, the braking effects of increasing economic and geopolitical uncertainties have become more apparent for manufacturers," said Rob Dobson, senior economist at Markit.
The manufacturing PMI for Germany, Russia's largest trading partner in the EU, fell to its lowest level in 11 months at 51.4.
Meanwhile, in France, the bloc's second-largest economy, the PMI fell to 46.9.
France remains a problem child, as does Italy's descent from solid expansion to stagnation.
"Indications that growth incentives in the key industrial mechanism in Germany as well as in Spain and the Netherlands are no longer effective are also not reassuring," said Mr. Dobson.
The decline in industry likely fuels the fire of analysts who expect further monetary or fiscal stimulus.
A positive message came from the Republic of Ireland, where the PMI rose to 57.3, the highest level since late 1999.

Howard Archer, chief economist at IHS Global Insight, said: "The best thing that can be said about the Eurozone manufacturing purchasing managers' index for August is that it indicates the sector continues to grow."

He added: "Producers in the Eurozone are obviously finding life quite difficult at the moment, as the current heightened geopolitical tensions - particularly regarding Russia and Ukraine - increase uncertainties in the already challenging conditions in many countries."
These increased uncertainties have clearly affected the economy - particularly consumer confidence - and likely lead to some orders being delayed or even canceled, especially large orders.
He said that it was becoming "increasingly likely" that the ECB would eventually have to initiate some form of QE, "although we suspect this will be limited."

If you would like to take photos or videos underwater, there is a selection of devices.
The most affordable option is a waterproof point-and-shoot camera, like the Nikon Coolpix AW120 or an action cam like the GoPro Hero3+ Silver Edition, both of which are available for around $300.
I took these photos at a family celebration with several cameras, all of which are available for under $350.
Regardless of the equipment, there are a few rules for the best results.
Check your equipment twice.
Even if you have a waterproof camera, make sure that the battery compartment and other compartments are tightly sealed.
Set your camera to the photos or videos you want to take.
Some cameras and camcorders have scene and recording modes that optimize exposure time for dim underwater conditions.
And before you jump in, check to what depth your equipment is functional.
Some cameras are only approved for up to 5 feet, others for up to 50 or 60 feet.
Search our buying guide and reviews for digital cameras, including conventional and waterproof models.
Take multiple shots - because many won't work out.
Point-and-shoot cameras have an LCD screen with which you can compose images, action cameras usually don't.
Even if you have an LCD, it is difficult to view it underwater, and getting the right image settings is a matter of luck.
So take lots of pictures/photos.
